items.title: SPELLDID - Software for Journalists created for Indiefferential
items.summary: Created by Indiefferential for Indie Voices Spelldid was developed exclusively for Indiefferential, built to reflect the platform’s mission of supporting…
items.content_html:
• Created by Indiefferential for Indie Voices
    Spelldid was developed exclusively for Indiefferential, built to reflect the platform’s mission of supporting new voices in journalism and cultural commentary.

  • A Smarter Editing Tool Without AI Dependence
    Unlike most writing aids that rely on generative AI, Spelldid was crafted over six months by a team of brilliant European computer engineers using traditional programming, ensuring transparency, consistency, and control.

  • Tailored for Pop Culture Storytelling
    Spelldid goes beyond grammar. It understands music, entertainment, and internet culture, helping writers make references that land and narratives that resonate.

  • Train as You Write
    Designed with early-career journalists in mind, Spelldid not only corrects mistakes, it explains them. Think of it as a built-in writing coach, offering clarity and guidance in real-time.

  • Industry-Savvy and Up-to-Date
    Whether it’s the latest album drop, meme trend, or cultural shift, Spelldid keeps editors in the loop, ensuring their content stays timely and relevant.

  • Editorial Quality, Indie Spirit
    Built with Indiefferential’s commitment to independent journalism at its core, Spelldid blends professional-grade editing features with the creativity and freedom of indie publishing.

  • Perfect for Internal Training and Growth
    As part of Indiefferential’s editorial toolkit, Spelldid supports new contributors by streamlining onboarding and elevating writing quality across the board.

items.title: Maddy Low: New Zealand’s Indie Prodigy Balancing Sunlit Joy and Soulful Reflection
items.summary: At just 18, Maddy Low is already carving her place in New Zealand’s indie scene with a sound that feels…
items.content_html:
At just 18, Maddy Low is already carving her place in New Zealand’s indie scene with a sound that feels both timeless and refreshingly her own. Splitting her time between Wellington and Auckland, she writes songs that swing between two poles — the quiet introspection of lying on your back, staring at the ceiling, and the euphoric rush of dancing under the sun.

 

Blending indie, folk, and pop with flashes of classic rock grit, Maddy’s guitar work reveals a maturity beyond her years. Since she first took to the streets as a 13-year-old busker, she’s honed an effortless connection with audiences, whether performing for passersby or commanding a live stage.

Her authenticity extends to her YouTube channel, where stripped-back, personal takes on songs by Amy Winehouse, The Cranberries, Olivia Rodrigo, and Sublime have resonated with thousands, proof that Maddy’s appeal lies in more than just skill; it’s in the emotional honesty she pours into every note.

Maddy Low is part storyteller, part soul-bearer, part sunshine,  and she’s only just getting started.

items.title: Welcome to Flow - Helsinki’s Crown Jewel of Festivals
items.summary: Every August, Helsinki’s Suvilahti transforms into a dazzling playground of music, art, and culture for Flow Festival. Known for its…
items.content_html:
Every August, Helsinki’s Suvilahti transforms into a dazzling playground of music, art, and culture for Flow Festival. Known for its genre-blending lineup, from cutting-edge electronic to boundary-pushing hip-hop, post-punk, and Nordic indie, Flow creates a space of sound across its intimate, massive and unique stages. But Flow is more than music: it’s where visual art installations glow in industrial spaces, street food tempts every taste bud, and design-forward details make every corner interesting. With its sustainable ethos, stylish crowd, and midnight sun vibes, Flow builds a feeling that is hard to describe. Whether you're here for deep beats, bold performances, or simply to soak in the city's most vibrant weekend, Flow promises a multisensory escape.

Photo by Petri Anttila and Samuli Pentti

Here are a few must-see shows at this year’s Flow Festival.

 Air – Moon Safari Live Set

Celebrating the 25th anniversary of Moon Safari, French duo Air have recently mounted full-album live shows in major venues like London and Vancouver. Critics hailed one such show at London's Coliseum as “a widescreen extravaganza” that transcended nostalgia. The show will be built on lush visuals, immersive staging and thick grooves, transforming Moon Safari into a living dreamscape. At Flow, this performance would offer a chill-out journey that's both cinematic and timeless.

Regina – Soita Mulle Live Set

The Finnish trio Regina revisits Soita Mulle, a cult indie-dream-pop album from 2011 featuring hushed dreampop tones and atmospheric grooves. Pitchfork praised vocalist Iisa Pykäri’s evolving clarity, calling it Regina’s most cohesive work to date. As a Finnish band performing a beloved domestic classic, their set would feel intimate and celebratory, perfect for music lovers eager for local legacy and dreamy heartfelt storytelling.

Bicep presents CHROMA – AV DJ set

Bicep’s Chroma AV DJ set is a hybrid audiovisual experience - a DJ mix built on their own tracks plus other mood-driven tracks synced tightly with custom visuals. Viewers called their Finsbury Park performance a “masterclass” of immersive electronic art. At Flow, this would be ideal for lovers of audiovisual spectacle.

Autechre

Autechre’s live sets are famously cryptic and immersive: long-form hour-plus pieces played in near darkness, building fractal percussive tension and alien chord structures. Their shows have been described as a sonic labyrinth that makes the venue “thrum” with uncanny energy. For Flow’s experimental crowd, experiencing Autechre live is entering a realm of pure electronic exploration, one not to skip.

Little Simz

Little Simz continues to impress critics and fans alike: closing Meltdown Festival with what one review termed a “dazzling, defiant orchestral triumph,” she married orchestral arrangement with raw rap emotion. Live reviewers note her infectious swagger onstage and the emotional depth of her vocals in intimate and arena settings alike. At Flow, her set would bring lyric-driven rap, orchestral textures, and commanding stage presence to a wider Finnish crowd.

Kneecap

Belfast’s Kneecap delivers high-energy rap fused with political provocation in Irish and English. Their live shows, fraught with call and response, mosh pits and socio-political rhetoric, have made them exhilarating and controversial at festivals like Glastonbury and Wide Awake. Despite legal scrutiny, fans describe their performances as “funny, anarchic and rebellious. Kneecap blends bold politics with big energy—don’t miss the chance to witness it live.

Oranssi Pazuzu

Finnish psych-black-metal pioneers Oranssi Pazuzu bring immersive, ritualistic live performances defined by dense sonic layering and self-engineered lighting that alter perception. In a Solstafir, Oranssi Pazuzu’s show, critics described being left “totally drained and energised” by the hypnotic set. Lovers of heavier music craving visceral psychedelia and sonic transcendence will find it here.

Major League DJz

South African twin duo Major League DJz have become international amapiano ambassadors, the first artists in the genre at Coachella, blending kwaito, Afrobeats and hip hop with infectious energy. Fans rave about their Boiler Room sets in Miami and Montreal, and DJ Mag praises their braggadocio with deep musicality. On Flow, they’ll bring dance-floor joy, global swagger, and shake up the dancefloor with a whole new groove.

Fontaines D.C.

Fontaines D.C. are set to deliver a post-punk performance that goes far beyond nostalgia—brimming with urgency, raw emotion, and present-day power. With their intense, heartfelt delivery, they draw in both devoted fans and curious newcomers alike, creating a collective moment of catharsis. It’s the kind of set that could very well become a defining highlight for post-punk lovers at this year’s Flow Festival.

From dreamy electronica to raw punk energy and bass-heavy grooves, Flow’s lineup is packed with unforgettable moments. Don’t miss your chance to catch these artists live—your perfect Flow experience starts here. See you in the crowd!

Photo by Petri Anttila and Samuli Pentti

items.title: Waking Iris Embraces Imperfection with Grit and Grace on New Single “Perfect”
items.summary: Fresh out of the underground scene in Kivenlahti, Finland, Waking Iris returns with their second single, “Perfect,” a moody, guitar-driven…
items.content_html:
Fresh out of the underground scene in Kivenlahti, Finland, Waking Iris returns with their second single, “Perfect,” a moody, guitar-driven anthem that delves into the emotional wreckage of infidelity. Led by Canadian vocalist and songwriter Brian Forth, the track marks a striking emotional departure from their high-octane debut “Rock Forever,” released in May, showcasing the band’s range and growing depth.

Written in the aftermath of Forth’s divorce, “Perfect” isn’t a song of blame or bitterness, it’s a somber acknowledgment of what it means to accept life’s imperfections. “Rather than wallow in self-pity, I wanted to write something that made peace with the reality that nothing is perfect in the end,” Forth shares. That emotional maturity resonates through the band’s searing guitar riffs, melancholic melodies, and a vocal performance that burns with both regret and release.

Backed by Finnish rock veterans, Waking Iris blends ’80s melodic rock with the grit of ’90s grunge. Lead guitarist Tim Norrgrann (Gtarzee) delivers soaring solos and layered textures, while Reda Kramdi’s dynamic drumming and Ilkka Pättiniemi’s pulsing bass lines drive the emotional weight forward. Pauliina Järvisalo’s keyboards add atmosphere and melodic nuance, rounding out the band’s sound with cinematic flair.

The track was recorded across borders, partly at Soundwell Studio in Finland with Valtteri Kallio, and at Stockholm’s Groundzero Studios with Swedish producers Joakim Hillson and Johan Öberg, who also handled mixing duties. Final mastering was completed by Tomas Caris Andersson at Carisma Studio in Sweden, giving “Perfect” a polished yet raw edge.

With “Perfect,” Waking Iris proves they’re not just another rock revival act, they’re a band unafraid to show vulnerability through volume, and heartache through harmony. As they continue to evolve, this single cements their place as one of Helsinki’s most compelling new rock exports.

items.title: Laura Pieri Releases “Daughter of Demeter (ON THE DANCEFLOOR)” – A Dark, Hypnotic Twist on Feminine Rage
items.summary: Brazilian-born pop provocateur Laura Pieri returns with a sleek and seductive reinvention of her 2024 single “Daughter of Demeter.” Titled…
items.content_html:
Brazilian-born pop provocateur Laura Pieri returns with a sleek and seductive reinvention of her 2024 single “Daughter of Demeter.” Titled “Daughter of Demeter (ON THE DANCEFLOOR),” this slow-burning remix leads the charge for the expanded edition of her Frankie EP, Frankie (ON THE DANCEFLOOR), arriving later this summer. The track will be joined by the equally alluring “Sea of Tragedy (ON THE DANCEFLOOR),” offering a fresh perspective on Pieri’s emotionally charged soundscape.

The original “Daughter of Demeter” was an electrified scream—a cathartic anthem born of heartbreak and fury. This new version trades raw defiance for calculated confidence, drawing power from restraint.

“This remix is what happens when that fire simmers into something slower, sharper, and slyer,” Pieri explains. “There’s a defiance in turning pain into pleasure. It lounges in heartbreak with style. It's rage on vacation.”

Produced with a hypnotic pulse and wrapped in cinematic textures, the remix magnifies Pieri’s fearless lyricism while expanding the emotional terrain of her artistry. Where Frankie was a declaration, Frankie (ON THE DANCEFLOOR) is a transformation.

“It made me rethink how we process and present emotion, especially feminine emotion,” says Pieri. “Sometimes healing looks like dancing. Sometimes grief shows up in a slow sway.”

Born in São Paulo and now splitting her time between New York and Los Angeles, Laura Pieri continues to blur the lines between high art and high energy, balancing the intensity of an MBA program by day with the liberation of pop stardom by night. Her music fuses glossy pop production with the deep emotional beats of her Brazilian heritage—music that dares you to feel deeply and move freely.

Frankie (ON THE DANCEFLOOR) builds on the powerful foundation laid by her original Frankie EP, released in May 2024 alongside an emotionally resonant short film. Co-written by an all-female team and executive produced by Skyler Cocco, the project marked Pieri’s defiant return from the brink of walking away—an artistic rebirth in real time.

With the arrival of Frankie (ON THE DANCEFLOOR), Pieri brings her voice back to the stage with even more clarity, sensuality, and control, ready to turn heartbreak into heat.

items.title: New Laconia’s “Stardust Bear Bazaar, Pt. 2”
items.summary: New Laconia returns with Stardust Bear Bazaar, Pt. 2 — a sprawling, genre-blending single that continues the otherworldly saga launched…
items.content_html:
New Laconia returns with Stardust Bear Bazaar, Pt. 2 — a sprawling, genre-blending single that continues the otherworldly saga launched in the project’s debut. At the helm is multi-instrumentalist and producer Alex Syniakov, who’s less interested in fitting into trends and more focused on reshaping the boundaries of modern music.

The result? A track that’s as cinematic as it is sonically daring.

At the core of New Laconia’s concept is a surreal setting: a cozy interdimensional pub trapped in a time loop and run by a mysterious figure known only as The Bear. If that sounds like the start of a science fiction novel, you’re not far off. The music itself acts as the narrative — bending genres and time signatures to echo the chaos and beauty of its fictional world.

Where Pt. 1 introduced the narrative with noir-tinged mystery and sci-fi tension, Pt. 2 dives deeper. We’re introduced to The Stranger, a stardust-drenched traveler navigating an altered reality, while the villainous force known as Time begins to manipulate the very fabric of the portals that connect their universe.

Musically, it’s a wild ride — but it never feels disjointed. Tenor vocals float over layered instrumentals that shift from pulsing distortion to delicate piano and saxophone. There’s a subtle elegance in the drumming, which evolves with the emotional arc of the story, and a sense of cinematic drama in the accordion and Arabic melodic motifs that weave through the track. These aren’t random genre mashups — each element feels placed with purpose, building tension or release in ways that genuinely surprise.

What’s especially impressive is how cohesive it all sounds. There’s a clear vision guiding the chaos. Even as the music twists and turns, you’re anchored by Syniakov’s vocal presence — emotionally charged, nuanced, and full of conviction. The storytelling doesn’t get lost in abstraction. Instead, it breathes through each instrumental choice and lyrical fragment.



There’s also something deeply personal under the cosmic cloak. The vocal delivery brings vulnerability to the conceptual sprawl — whether The Bear is trying to alter his past or The Stranger is stumbling through altered realities, the emotional stakes are clear. Syniakov has tapped into the power of narrative not just as a backdrop but as a structural foundation for sound itself.

“Stardust Bear Bazaar, Pt. 2” isn’t just a sequel — it’s a sonic expansion of an already rich world. It teases the larger promise of New Laconia’s upcoming debut album, a project poised to become a sci-fi symphony of genre fusion. If this track is any indication, we’re in for something rare: music that experiments without ego, stories that transport without confusion, and vocals that stir the soul even while dancing across galaxies.

New Laconia has created something that’s not just heard but experienced. “Stardust Bear Bazaar, Pt. 2” is not just a song — it’s a portal. Step through it.
